3384038191.resolved_title: A Peek Inside the World’s Greatest Record Store
3384038191.excerpt: I first heard about Val Shively—a legendary figure among serious record collectors—from a friend of mine in Philadelphia named Aaron Levinson. He’s a Grammy-winning music producer, composer, DJ and rare vinyl collector who has been buying records from Shively for 40 years.

1.caption:
Shively presides over the store six days a week, from noon to 6, and regards his business as a calling. By selling records, he says, “I make people happy. That’s what I do for a living.”
    
    
      Jason Varney

2.caption:
Val Shively at his shop, in Philadelphia, home to more than four million 45s. His customers know what they want. “You can’t come in here and just look around,” he says.
    
    
      Jason Varney

3.caption:
Left, “I’m Coming Home,” by Buddy Lamp,  represents another sought-after vintage treasure tucked away in Shively’s inventory. Right, “Take no prisoners” is a warning applied to would-be shoplifters inside the store.
    
    
      Jason Varney

4.caption: Left, this recording of “Love Is a Vow” by the 1950s Brooklyn-based Mello-Harps has been valued at $10,000. Fewer than five copies exist. Right, according to Shively, 45-year employee Chuck Dabagian

5.credit: Michael Ochs Archives / Getty Images (2); Afro American Newspapers / Gado / Getty Images
5.caption: Left, powerhouse vocalist Jeanette “Baby” Washington

6.caption:
Left, by 1973, Shively was running ads in Bim Bam Boom, an oldies magazine. Above right, at Times Square Records in Manhattan, a teenage Shively, in hat, with owner Irving “Slim” Rose. Below right, Shively with one of many rarities, a plastic pressing of “Miss You” by the Crows.
    
    
      Val Shively

7.caption:
Left, “Stormy Weather,” in a spoof reproduction record produced by Shively, alludes to another song by the Five Chimes—an original 45 from the 1950s has never surfaced. Right, sometimes even Shively feels overwhelmed by the store’s vast holdings, which encompass superstars and unsung talents. “I don’t run this place,” he says, “it runs me.”
    
    
      Jason Varney

8.caption:
The Van Dykes, a Fort Worth, Texas, trio, issued their first single,“No Man is an Island,” written by founder Rondalis Tandy, in 1965. They would later perform at the Apollo Theater.
    
    
      Mark Peterman

9.caption:
Left, “RoseMarie,” by the Five Chimes, from the 1950s, typifies the hidden gems in Shively’s collections. Right, “Who needs a computer?” Shively asks, when a Rolodex system fills the bill. 


    
    
      Jason Varney
